repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second Social Development -
            Health and Nutrition Project (FASBASE)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Social
            Development: Health and Nutrition Project (FASBASE) is rated
            as satisfactory, sustainability as likely, institutional
            development impact as substantial, Bank performance as
            highly satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The Project faced severe constraints
            associated with the economic, epidemiologic, and natural
            environment. Some key lessons were drawn from the project
            implementation. 1) The application of targeting criteria
            responded well to the fiscal constraints. 2) Pilot testing
            is appropriate at early stages of policy implementation. 3)
            Public-private partnerships are effective in micronutrient
            fortification programs. 4) Municipal government, community
            involvement, and innovative counterpart arrangements can
            buffer the project from economic shocks. 5) Emergencies can
            bring about better implementation results if coupled with
            good technical and implementation capabilities. 6)
            Continuity in Bank task management helps to reduce the
            impact of turnover on the Borrower side. 7) Project
            activities that imply a significant recurrent cost burden
            should be reassessed - and possibly redesigned - in light of
            new economic conditions. 8) The development of an emergency
            services network yielded high returns. 9) Program management
            experience and continuity is essential at all stages of
            implementation, and can ensure timely execution.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Second Social Development :
            Health and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has four main components.
            The first is a basic health care component which will
            support the Ministry of Health (MOH)'s Basic Health
            Care Program in extending coverage of and in improving the
            quality of basic health care services to the poor. This
            component is centered around maternal and child health care
            interventions and includes: i) cost-effective health care
            teams at local health facilities; ii) upgrading of
            facilities; and iii) medical inputs and essential drugs on a
            cost-recovery basis. The second is a nutrition component
            containing subcomponents in information, dissemination, and
            non-formal education, growth monitoring, and food
            supplementation. Activities financed will include:
            educational campaigns advocating good general nutrition,
            feeding practices, and breastfeeding. Third, a basic
            sanitation and safe water component will assist MOH in
            improving access to safe water and sanitation facilities in
            rural areas. Finally, a sector policy and institutional
            strengthening component will support: (a) development of
            institutional basis for decentralization; (b) staff
            development; and (c) studies devoted to improved
            inter-institutional coordination, cost recovery and payment
            systems, hospital rehabilitation, and impact evaluation of
            project activities and other activities in the public health sector.
